newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: NZ's CHH seen emerging from commodities gloom.
newsitem.headline: NZ's CHH seen emerging from commodities gloom.

text.p: Forest products group Carter Holt Harvey Ltd on Thursday showed tentative signs that it was slowly emerging from the depths of a commodities slump with a slight improvement in second quarter earnings.

First half earnings for the International Paper-controlled CHH slumped to NZ$118 million (US$83.8 million) in the six months to September from $271 million a year earlier, but second quarter earnings were up at $62 million from $56 million in the first quarter.
Analysts said the first quarter probably reflected the worst of the pulp and paper cycle but they did not rule out the possibility further price falls, despite recent improvements.

Chief Executive John Faraci told analysts and journalists the company had already realised NZ$8.0 million in cost savings, was on target for $25 million in the current year and for savings of $50 million in 1997/8.
"I would say I'm cautiously optimistic, but clearly our second quarter was an improvement over the first quarter," he said.
There had been price improvements in paper businesses but most of the quarter-to-quarter gain came from better margins and efficiency gains.
"I don't see a good snap back in either log markets or in the wood markets although I think the correction from here is up, it will be up at a fairly modest pace," Faraci said.
He saw little likelihood of "price spikes" on the horizon, so earnings improvements would therefore come from within the company as opposed to market-led factors.
Faraci said he saw continued growth of the company in a planned and managed way and its recent acquisition for A$125 million of Australia's Forward Products was an example of that.
The Forward purchase made CHH the second largest marketer of wood products in the Australian market, he said.

David Stanley at Doyle Paterson Brown said he was confident the company's second half would be better than the first and analysts generally expect a full year result in the high NZ$200 millions against the previous year's record of NZ$453 million.
The first half result was in line with expectations, but the company's operating performance was a little better than anticipated.
Since the start of the financial year, the price of softwood pulp and risen to US$550 from $500 per tonne.
But there was still uncertainty in the industry and a risk that pulp and paper prices could still drop.

"It's really in the hands of the northern hemisphere pulp producers as to what happens there," Doyle Paterson's Stanley said. "If they restrain production then the market should tighten going into 1997," he said.
"Despite that, the second half -- under most scenarios -- is going to be better because wood products are looking better."

Francis Loo at SBC Warburg said opinions varied on the commodities outlook, but that SBC belonged to the "slow recovery scenario". However, the overall picture of the company was one where its three main businesses were at the bottom of their cycles rather than the top.
"The only question will be the quantum of pickup and I guess that's the question that is on everybody's mind at the moment," Loo said.
